data.title: The Historic Record Plant Recording Studio Sausalito
data.meta_description: Record Plant Sausalito studios, now closed, where Santana, the Grateful Dead, Carrie Underwood, Fleetwood Mac, Journey and many others recorded their hits.
data.text:
Click here to go to the Fun Things to Do in Sausalito Menu

The Record Plant Sausalito

What do Fleetwood Mac, Stevie Wonder, Bob Marley and the Wailers, The Grateful Dead, Carlos Santana, Sammy Hagar, Rick James, Van Morrison, Huey Lewis, Aretha Franklin, Heart, Train, Carrie Underwood, John Fogerty, Journey, The Doobie Brothers, Celine Dion, Tracy Chapman, Metallica, Luther Vandross, New Kids On the Block, Chris Isaak, The Dave Matthews Band, Mariah Carey, Michael Bolton, Harry Connick Jr., Marky Mark, Joe Walsh, Third Eye Blind, Joe Satriani, Linda Ronstadt and The Fray have in common?

2200 Bridgeway, Sausalito CA 94965 (Closed to the public, but you can drive by)

Please scroll down for a list of some of the famous albums that were recorded here.

Fleetwood Mac recorded Rumours here (not to mention both couples in the band breaking up during the process), which was released in 1977 and has sold over 40 million copies. On a trip to California several years ago Mick Fleetwood dropped by to visit the place where they became a super-band, and was horrified to find it shuttered. The YouTube video he recorded in support of its preservation is below.

November, 2020 Update: After years of unsuccessful negotiations by various groups, local investors have negotiated a deal to buy the building and open a recording studio and community music center and museum. We are in touch with them and will share more information shortly.

Insiders Tip: If you want to stop by and see the exterior, the Bridgeway address is misleading because the location is actually on Marinship Way. It’s across the street from the Bay Model Visitors Center, which also has a confusing Bridgeway address while being located on Marinship Way. Scroll down to the bottom of the page for a map that shows you how to get to Marinship Way from Bridgeway!

Scroll down for a partial list of major artists and their albums recorded at The Record Plant in Sausalito, including Whitney Houston, Metallica, Carrie Underwood, The Grateful Dead and many more

History of the Record Plant in Sausalito

In 1972 a famous recording studio in New York and Los Angeles called The Record Plant founded its third location here in Sausalito. Later renamed The Plant Studios, the facility at 2200 Bridgeway closed in 2008 after almost four decades hosting artists from Andrea Bocelli to Metallica, and from Santana to Carrie Underwood.

Several different teams, foundations and local music fans are all trying to build alliances and raise funds to buy the semi-vacant building and preserve it in some form related to music and musicians.

In the meantime the building is for sale, and hosts occasional classes and musical performances. Located just down the street from the OurSausalito.com offices, the main studio area spends most of its time empty.

Half of the complex has been subdivided and repurposed as architectural offices, although the unique diagonal wooden siding to the buildings betrays their heritage as part of the Record Plant.

The Record Plant was both studio and luxury resort, with musicians who were recording here being housed on the property in suites custom-renovated for the tastes of each new arrival. Stories circulated that for Rick James‘ visits a waterbed was installed that filled the entire floor of a conference-room-turned-bedroom.

The beautiful inlaid-wood front doors, which remain in place, were created by local artist Dave Richards, who also custom-painted Janis Joplin’s Porsche and designed the (now thoughtfully preserved) murals and interior woodwork at The Trident.

The old Record Plant building still does offer an occasional surprise. I was driving back to my office from lunch a couple of years ago and saw Ann and Nancy Wilson of Heart, who just happened to be laughing and taking a stroll down Marinship Way. Audio equipment was being moved into the building, a sign that occasional recording or rehearsal activity still is going on there.

I resisted the temptation to stop and ask them for an autograph. That’s a courtesy I learned from a friend who became an instantly-recognized public figure. On the rare occasions when we still get to grab lunch together, he is interrupted by autograph seekers every few minutes. It’s fun for us as the fans, but stops being fun for the famous people we love.
